Q-G1.query: Across the agreements, list the **termination/cancellation** rules you can find.

evidence_path_sig: Power system: 110 VAC 60 Hz up, 12 VAC down
Aluminum door with plexi-glass inserts & automatic opener
runs.text:
Below is a document‑by‑document summary of all **termination/cancellation** rules, with explicit notice periods, cancellation windows, and refund/forfeiture outcomes where stated.

---

## 1. BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY WITH ARBITRATION (Fabrikam Inc. ↔ Contoso Ltd.)

### a. Automatic termination by passage of time

- The warranty coverage begins on the **date of final settlement** or the **date when the Buyer/Owner first occupies the home**, whichever comes first. [1][2][3][5][11]  
- The warranty **terminates** after either **one (1) year** or **sixty (60) days**, depending on the specific coverage, measured from that commencement date. [1][2][3][5][11]  
- Any claims not made in writing within the applicable **one (1) year** or **sixty (60) day** period are **not covered** (“ANY CLAIMS WHICH HAVE NOT BEEN MADE IN WRITING… WITHIN ONE (1) YEAR OR SIXTY (60) AS APPLICABLE… ARE NOT COVERED”). This functions as a time‑based termination of coverage for unasserted claims. [2][3][5][11]

### b. Termination upon transfer of the home

- The warranty is **“Not Transferable”** and is extended only to the first purchaser (Contoso Ltd. as Buyer/Owner). [1][2][3][5][11]  
- If the first purchaser **sells the home** or **moves out of it**, the limited warranty **“automatically terminates.”** [1][2][3][5][11]

### c. Survival of arbitration provisions after termination

- The Arbitration Program explicitly states that its provisions **“shall survive any termination, amendment, or expiration hereof or of the Documents unless the Parties otherwise expressly agree in writing.”** [12]  
- This means that even after the warranty itself terminates (by time or by sale/move‑out), the obligation to arbitrate disputes continues unless the parties agree otherwise in writing. [12]

### d. No separate “cancellation” right / no refund rule

- The warranty text does **not** provide a discretionary “right to cancel” by either party within a set number of days, nor any refund/forfeiture rule tied to cancellation. It only provides:
  - Time‑limited coverage (1 year / 60 days). [2][3][5][11]  
  - Automatic termination on sale/move‑out. [1][2][3][5][11]  
- Therefore, this document has **termination rules** (time‑based and transfer‑based) but **no explicit cancellation window with refund/forfeiture** like the purchase contract below.

---

## 2. PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT (Short Term/Vacation Rentals)  
**Parties: Contoso Ltd. (Owner) and Walt Flood Realty (Agent)**

### a. Term and renewal

- The agreement has an **initial period of twelve months** beginning on **2010-06-15**. [4][7][13]  
- It is **“automatically renewed for successive one year terms thereafter.”** [4][7][13]

### b. Sixty (60) days written notice termination right

- Either party may terminate the agreement **“upon sixty (60) days written notice.”** [4][7][13]  
- This is a mutual termination right; no cause is required in the text. [4][7][13]

### c. Effect of termination on existing rental agreements and obligations

- **Existing rental agreements remain valid:**  
  “Termination of this agreement does not invalidate any existing rental agreements made by Agent on Owner's behalf.” [4][7][13]  
- **Owner remains responsible for obligations/expenses incurred by Agent:**  
  “Upon termination, Owner shall continue to be responsible or shall cause to be completed all obligations or expenses incurred hereunder by the Agent.” [4][7][13]

### d. Confirmed reservations must be honored after termination or sale

- The agreement states:  
  “In the event this agreement is terminated, or the property is sold, the Owner shall honor all confirmed reservations.” [4][7][13]  
- This creates a continuing obligation for Contoso Ltd. (Owner) to honor reservations even after:
  - Termination by **60 days written notice**, or  
  - Sale of the property. [4][7][13]

### e. No explicit refund/forfeiture rule

- The Property Management Agreement does **not** specify any **refund** or **deposit forfeiture** mechanism tied to termination (e.g., no clause saying the Owner or Agent must refund or may keep any particular deposit upon termination). [4][7][13]  
- Thus, it has a **“sixty (60) days written notice”** termination mechanism but **no explicit cancellation window with a refund/forfeiture outcome.** [4][7][13]

---

## 3. HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT  
**Parties: Contoso Ltd. (Owner) and Fabrikam Inc. (Pumper)**

### a. Open‑ended term with termination by either party

- The contract states:  
  “This agreement will remain in effect until the owner or pumper terminates this contract.” [6][14]  
- This creates an **indefinite term** that continues until either Contoso Ltd. (Owner) or Fabrikam Inc. (Pumper) chooses to terminate. [6][14]

### b. No specified notice period

- The contract does **not** specify any **notice period** (e.g., no “30 days” or “60 days” requirement) for termination by either party. [6][14]  
- Therefore, there is a termination right, but the timing and form of notice are not defined in the text. [6][14]

### c. Obligation to file changes/new contract within 10 business days

- If there is a **change in this contract**, the owner must file a copy of any changes or a new service contract with the municipality and County **“within ten (10) business days from the date of change to this service contract.”** [6][14]  
- This **10 business days** requirement is an administrative filing obligation triggered by a change (which could include termination and replacement), not a notice period for termination itself. [6][14]

### d. No cancellation window / no refund or forfeiture rule

- The contract contains **no “right to cancel” window** (e.g., no “3 business days” or similar) and **no refund/forfeiture** language regarding any deposit or prepayment. [6][14]  
- Thus, it has a **termination right** (either party may terminate) but **no defined cancellation period or refund rule.** [6][14]

---

## 4. PURCHASE CONTRACT (Contoso Lifts LLC ↔ Fabrikam Inc.)

### a. Right to cancel – 3 business days

- The contract includes a specific **“Right to Cancel”** clause:  
  “Customer may cancel within **3 business days** for full refund.” [9][10][15]  
- This is an explicit **3 business days cancellation period** during which the Customer (Fabrikam Inc.) can cancel the contract. [9][10][15]

### b. Refund/forfeiture outcome tied to the cancellation window

- The same clause states: **“Afterward, deposit is forfeited.”** [9][10][15]  
- Therefore:
  - If the Customer cancels **within 3 business days**, they receive a **full refund**. [9][10][15]  
  - If the Customer cancels **after 3 business days**, the **deposit is forfeited** (i.e., the Contractor keeps the deposit). [9][10][15]

### c. Relationship to payment terms and deposit

- The total contract price is **$29,900.00**, payable in **3 installments**:  
  - **$20,000.00 upon signing**  
  - **$7,000.00 upon delivery**  
  - **$2,900.00 upon completion** [9][10][15]  
- The “deposit” referenced in the forfeiture clause is logically the **$20,000.00 upon signing**, which is the initial payment made when the contract becomes effective (“effective upon mutual signature and initial payment”). [9][10][15]  
- Thus, the **3 business days** cancellation right effectively governs whether that **$20,000.00** initial payment is fully refundable (if within 3 business days) or forfeited (if after 3 business days). [9][10][15]

### d. No separate long‑term termination clause

- Beyond the **3 business days** cancellation right and the general default clause (“Failure to pay may result in legal action”), the contract does **not** provide a general long‑term termination right (e.g., no “either party may terminate on 30 days’ notice”). [9][10][15]  
- Termination/cancellation is therefore primarily governed by:
  - The **3 business days** cancellation window with full refund vs. deposit forfeiture. [9][10][15]  
  - Remedies for **Customer Default** (legal action, recovery of legal fees) rather than a mutual termination mechanism. [9][10][15]

---

## 5. contoso_lifts_invoice (Contoso Lifts LLC Invoice to Fabrikam Construction)

- The invoice is a billing document showing an **INVOICE # 1256003**, total **$29,900.00**, and terms “Due on contract signing,” but it **does not contain any termination or cancellation clause.** [8]  
- It references “Initial payment in accordance with contract,” which ties it conceptually to a contract, but the invoice itself has **no termination/cancellation mechanism, no notice period, and no refund/forfeiture rule.** [8]

---

## 6. Cross‑document connections and comparison

### a. Shared parties and related obligations

- **Contoso Ltd.** appears as:
  - Buyer/Owner in the **Builders Limited Warranty** with Fabrikam Inc. (Builder). [1][5][11]  
  - Owner in the **Property Management Agreement** with Walt Flood Realty. [4][7][13]  
  - Holding Tank Owner in the **Holding Tank Servicing Contract** with Fabrikam Inc. (Pumper). [6][14]  
- **Fabrikam Inc.** appears as:
  - Builder in the **Builders Limited Warranty**. [1][5][11]  
  - Pumper in the **Holding Tank Servicing Contract**. [6][14]  
  - Customer in the **Purchase Contract** with Contoso Lifts LLC. [9][10][15]  
- **Contoso Lifts LLC** appears as:
  - Contractor in the **Purchase Contract**. [9][10][15]  
  - Payee in the **contoso_lifts_invoice**. [8]

These relationships show that the same entities are subject to different termination/cancellation regimes across different contracts.

### b. Summary of distinct notice periods and cancellation windows

Across all agreements, the explicit time‑based termination/cancellation rules are:

1. **Builders Limited Warranty**  
   - Coverage terminates after **one (1) year** or **sixty (60) days** from commencement, depending on the item. [2][3][5][11]  
   - Warranty automatically terminates if the first purchaser **sells the home** or **moves out**. [1][2][3][5][11]  
   - Arbitration provisions **survive any termination, amendment, or expiration** unless otherwise agreed in writing. [12]  
   - **No refund/forfeiture rule** tied to cancellation. [1][2][3][5][11][12]

2. **Property Management Agreement**  
   - Either party may terminate on **sixty (60) days written notice**. [4][7][13]  
   - Upon termination, Owner must still honor **all confirmed reservations** and remain responsible for obligations/expenses incurred by Agent. [4][7][13]  
   - **No explicit refund/forfeiture rule** for any deposits or fees upon termination. [4][7][13]

3. **Holding Tank Servicing Contract**  
   - Agreement remains in effect until **owner or pumper terminates** (no specified notice period). [6][14]  
   - Owner must file changes/new contract within **ten (10) business days** of any change to the service contract (administrative filing, not a termination notice period). [6][14]  
   - **No cancellation window** and **no refund/forfeiture rule**. [6][14]

4. **Purchase Contract (Contoso Lifts LLC)**  
   - Customer may cancel within **3 business days** for **full refund**. [9][10][15]  
   - If cancellation occurs **after 3 business days**, the **deposit is forfeited**. [9][10][15]  
   - Total price **$29,900.00** with **$20,000.00 upon signing**, which functions as the deposit governed by this rule. [9][10][15]

5. **contoso_lifts_invoice**  
   - **No termination or cancellation mechanism** stated. [8]

---

### Direct answer to the query

Across the agreements:

- **Termination by notice:**  
  - Property Management Agreement: mutual termination on **60 days written notice**, with Owner still obligated to honor confirmed reservations and existing obligations. [4][7][13]  
  - Holding Tank Servicing Contract: either party may terminate at any time (no notice period specified). [6][14]

- **Automatic/structural termination:**  
  - Builders Limited Warranty: coverage ends after **1 year** or **60 days** from commencement, and automatically terminates if the first purchaser sells or moves out; arbitration obligations survive termination. [1][2][3][5][11][12]

- **Cancellation windows with refund/forfeiture:**  
  - Purchase Contract (Contoso Lifts LLC): Customer may cancel within **3 business days** for **full refund**; if cancellation occurs after **3 business days**, the **deposit is forfeited**. [9][10][15]

- **Documents with no termination/cancellation mechanism:**  
  - contoso_lifts_invoice: contains **no termination or cancellation clause**. [8]

runs.text:
Below is a document-by-document summary of all **termination / cancellation** rules, with explicit notice periods, cancellation windows, and refund/forfeiture outcomes.

---

## 1. Builders Limited Warranty (Fabrikam Inc. ↔ Contoso Ltd.)

**a. Automatic termination by passage of time**

- The warranty coverage begins on the **date of final settlement** or the date when the **Buyer/Owner first occupies the home**, whichever comes first. [2][3][5][11]  
- The warranty **terminates** after either:
  - **one (1) year** for the one‑year coverages, or  
  - **sixty (60) days** for the 60‑day coverages,  
  measured from commencement. [2][3][5][11]  
- Any claims **not made in writing** within the applicable **one (1) year** or **sixty (60) day** period are **not covered** (“ANY CLAIMS WHICH HAVE NOT BEEN MADE IN WRITING … WITHIN ONE (1) YEAR OR SIXTY (60) AS APPLICABLE, REGARDLESS OF DISCOVERABILITY, ARE NOT COVERED.”). [2][3][5][11]

**b. Termination upon transfer of the home**

- The warranty is **not transferable** and is extended only to the **Buyer/Owner as the first purchaser of the home**. [2][3][5][11]  
- If the **first purchaser sells the home or moves out of it**, the limited warranty **automatically terminates**. [2][3][5][11]

**c. Arbitration program survival after termination**

- The **Arbitration Program provisions** expressly **survive any termination, amendment, or expiration** of the warranty or related “Documents,” unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in writing. [12]  
- This means that even after the warranty term ends or the warranty is otherwise terminated, the arbitration clause remains in effect unless both parties agree in writing to change that. [12]

**d. No separate “cancellation” right**

- There is **no explicit customer or builder right to cancel** the warranty at will; termination is tied to:
  - expiration of the **one (1) year** or **sixty (60) day** term, [2][3][5][11] and  
  - sale of the home or the first purchaser moving out. [2][3][5][11]  
- The documents do **not** specify any refund or forfeiture mechanism upon termination; they only state that claims outside the term are not covered. [2][3][5][11]

---

## 2. Property Management Agreement (Contoso Ltd. ↔ Walt Flood Realty)

**a. Term and renewal**

- The agreement has an **initial period of twelve months** beginning on **2010-06-15** and is **automatically renewed for successive one year terms** thereafter. [4][7][13]

**b. Sixty (60) days written notice termination right**

- **Either party** (Owner or Agent) may **terminate** the agreement **upon sixty (60) days written notice**. [4][7][13]  
- This is a clear **“60 days written notice” termination right** for both sides. [4][7][13]

**c. Effect of termination on existing rental agreements**

- **Termination does not invalidate any existing rental agreements** made by the Agent on the Owner’s behalf. [4][7][13]  
- Upon termination, the **Owner shall continue to be responsible** or shall cause to be completed **all obligations or expenses incurred** under the agreement by the Agent. [4][7][13]

**d. Confirmed reservations must be honored after termination or sale**

- If the agreement is **terminated**, or if the **property is sold**, the **Owner shall honor all confirmed reservations**. [4][13]  
- This creates a continuing obligation that survives termination or sale with respect to already confirmed bookings. [4][13]

**e. Refund / forfeiture**

- The agreement **does not specify** any refund or forfeiture of fees or commissions upon termination. It only addresses ongoing responsibility for obligations and honoring reservations. [4][7][13]

---

## 3. Holding Tank Servicing Contract (Contoso Ltd. ↔ Fabrikam Inc.)

**a. Open-ended term with termination by either party**

- The contract states: “This agreement will remain in effect **until the owner or pumper terminates this contract**.” [6][14]  
- This gives **both the owner and the pumper** a right to terminate, but **no specific notice period** (e.g., days) is stated. [6][14]

**b. Obligations upon change/termination**

- In the event of a **change in this contract**, the owner agrees to **file a copy of any changes to this service contract or a copy of a new service contract** with the municipality and the County within **ten (10) business days** from the date of change. [6][14]  
- While this “ten (10) business days” requirement is framed around **changes** or a **new service contract**, it effectively governs the owner’s obligation to notify authorities when the service arrangement is altered or replaced, which would typically occur upon termination or replacement of the pumper. [6][14]

**c. Refund / forfeiture**

- The contract **does not mention** any refund or forfeiture of payments upon termination. [6][14]

---

## 4. Purchase Contract for Lift (Contoso Lifts LLC ↔ Fabrikam Inc.)

**a. Right to cancel – 3 business days cancellation period**

- The contract includes a **“Right to Cancel”** clause:  
  - The **Customer may cancel within 3 business days for full refund**. [9][10][15]  
  - This is an explicit **“3 business days” cancellation period**. [9][10][15]

**b. Deposit forfeiture after cancellation period**

- The same clause states that **afterward, deposit is forfeited**. [9][10][15]  
- Thus:
  - If the Customer cancels **within 3 business days**, they receive a **full refund** of the deposit. [9][10][15]  
  - If the Customer cancels **after 3 business days**, the **deposit is forfeited** (i.e., not refunded). [9][10][15]

**c. Contract effectiveness**

- The contract is **effective upon mutual signature and initial payment**, meaning the cancellation right operates after the contract has become effective. [9][10][15]

**d. No separate long-term termination clause**

- Beyond the **3 business days** cancellation right and deposit forfeiture rule, the contract does **not provide a general at‑will termination right** for either party later in the project. [9][10][15]  
- Other clauses address **customer default** (failure to pay may result in legal action and recovery of legal fees) but do not create a separate termination window with refunds. [9][10][15]

---

## 5. Contoso Lifts LLC Invoice

- The **invoice** from Contoso Lifts LLC is a billing document and **does not contain any termination or cancellation mechanism**. It lists items, prices, and payment terms (“Due on contract signing”) but no cancellation rights or notice periods. [8]  
- Therefore, **no termination/cancellation rules are present in the invoice itself**. [8]

---

## 6. Cross-Document Observations and Connections

**a. Different types of termination/cancellation mechanisms**

- **Time-based warranty expiration**:  
  - Builders Limited Warranty terminates after **one (1) year** or **sixty (60) days**, depending on the coverage, and is non-transferable; it also terminates automatically if the first purchaser sells or moves out. [2][3][5][11]
- **Notice-based contract termination**:  
  - Property Management Agreement allows either party to terminate with **sixty (60) days written notice**, while preserving existing rental agreements and requiring the Owner to honor confirmed reservations. [4][7][13]
- **Open-ended service contract termination**:  
  - Holding Tank Servicing Contract remains in effect until either the **owner or pumper terminates**, with no specified notice period, but requires filing changes or a new contract with authorities within **ten (10) business days**. [6][14]
- **Short cancellation window with deposit consequences**:  
  - Purchase Contract for the lift gives the Customer **3 business days** to cancel for a **full refund**, after which the **deposit is forfeited**. [9][10][15]

**b. Refund / forfeiture outcomes summarized**

- **Builders Limited Warranty**:  
  - No explicit refund or forfeiture rules; termination affects coverage, not payments. [2][3][5][11]
- **Property Management Agreement**:  
  - No explicit refund/forfeiture; termination preserves existing rental obligations and confirmed reservations. [4][7][13]
- **Holding Tank Servicing Contract**:  
  - No refund/forfeiture language; only ongoing service and reporting obligations plus filing changes within **ten (10) business days**. [6][14]
- **Purchase Contract (Lift)**:  
  - **Within 3 business days**: **full refund**. [9][10][15]  
  - **After 3 business days**: **deposit is forfeited**. [9][10][15]

**c. Entities and relationships**

- **Contoso Ltd.** appears as:
  - Buyer/Owner in the **Builders Limited Warranty** with Fabrikam Inc. [1][5][11]  
  - Property Owner in the **Property Management Agreement** with Walt Flood Realty. [4][7][13]  
  - Holding Tank Owner in the **Holding Tank Servicing Contract** with Fabrikam Inc. [6][14]  
- **Contoso Lifts LLC** is the Contractor in the **Purchase Contract** and issuer of the related **invoice**, but only the Purchase Contract contains cancellation rules. [8][9][10][15]  
- The **Arbitration Program** in the Builders Limited Warranty explicitly survives **termination, amendment, or expiration**, showing that some dispute-resolution obligations continue even after the main warranty term ends. [12]

---

### Consolidated List of Distinct Notice Periods / Cancellation Windows

- **“one (1) year”** warranty term (Builders Limited Warranty). [2][3][5][11]  
- **“sixty (60) days”** warranty term for certain items (Builders Limited Warranty). [2][3][5][11]  
- **Automatic termination upon sale or move-out by first purchaser** (Builders Limited Warranty). [2][3][5][11]  
- **“sixty (60) days written notice”** termination right for either party (Property Management Agreement). [4][7][13]  
- **“ten (10) business days”** to file changes or a new service contract with municipality and County after a change in the service contract (Holding Tank Servicing Contract). [6][14]  
- **“3 business days”** cancellation period for full refund; **afterward, deposit is forfeited** (Purchase Contract for lift). [9][10][15]

runs.text:
Below is a document-by-document summary of all **termination / cancellation** rules, with explicit notice periods, cancellation windows, and refund/forfeiture outcomes where stated.

---

## 1. Builders Limited Warranty (Fabrikam Inc. ↔ Contoso Ltd.)

**Document:** BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY WITH ARBITRATION / “2. Term” and related sections [1][2][3][5][11][12]

### 1.1. Automatic Termination by Passage of Time

- The warranty coverage begins on the **date of final settlement** or the date when the Buyer/Owner first occupies the home, **whichever comes first**. [1][2][3][5][11]  
- The warranty **terminates** after either:
  - **1 year** for the one‑year coverages, or  
  - **60 days** for the sixty‑day coverages,  
  measured from commencement. [1][2][3][5][11]  
- Any claims **not made in writing** within the applicable **1 year** or **60 days** period are **not covered** (“ANY CLAIMS WHICH HAVE NOT BEEN MADE IN WRITING … WITHIN ONE (1) YEAR OR SIXTY (60) AS APPLICABLE, REGARDLESS OF DISCOVERABILITY, ARE NOT COVERED.”). This functions as a termination of claim rights after those periods. [2][3][5][11]

**Effect:** After the relevant **1 year** or **60 days** from commencement, the warranty coverage ends and no new claims can be made. [2][3][5][11]

### 1.2. Termination on Transfer of the Home

- The warranty is **“Not Transferable”** and is extended only to the Buyer/Owner as the **first purchaser**. [1][2][3][5][11]  
- If the first purchaser **sells the home** or **moves out of it**, the limited warranty **“automatically terminates.”** [1][2][3][5][11]

**Effect:** Sale of the home or the first purchaser moving out is an automatic termination event; no notice period is specified. [1][2][3][5][11]

### 1.3. Arbitration Program – Survival After Termination

- The arbitration provisions explicitly state that the **“provisions of this Arbitration Program shall survive any termination, amendment, or expiration hereof or of the Documents unless the Parties otherwise expressly agree in writing.”** [12]  
- “Documents” include the warranty and related agreements. [1][12]

**Effect:** Even if the warranty terminates (by time lapse, sale, or moving out), the arbitration clause continues to apply to disputes unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in writing. [12]

### 1.4. No Separate Early Termination Right

- There is **no clause** granting either party a general right to terminate the warranty early by notice (e.g., no “60 days written notice” termination right in this document). [1][2][3][5][11][12]  
- Termination mechanisms are limited to:
  - Expiry after **1 year** or **60 days**, and  
  - Automatic termination upon sale or move‑out by the first purchaser. [1][2][3][5][11]

---

## 2. Property Management Agreement (Contoso Ltd. ↔ Walt Flood Realty)

**Document:** PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT (Short Term and/or Vacation/Holiday Rentals) [4][7][13]

### 2.1. Term and Renewal

- Initial term: **twelve months** beginning on **2010‑06‑15**. [4][7][13]  
- The agreement is **automatically renewed** for successive **one year** terms thereafter. [4][7][13]

### 2.2. Sixty (60) Days Written Notice Termination Right

- Either party may terminate:  
  - “However, either party upon **sixty (60) days written notice** may terminate this agreement.” [4][7][13]

**Effect:** Both Owner (Contoso Ltd.) and Agent (Walt Flood Realty) have a mutual right to terminate at any time, provided they give **60 days written notice**. [4][7][13]

### 2.3. Obligations Surviving Termination

- Termination **does not invalidate any existing rental agreements** made by Agent on Owner’s behalf. [4][7][13]  
- Upon termination, Owner must **continue to be responsible** or cause to be completed **all obligations or expenses incurred** by the Agent under the agreement. [4][7][13]  
- If the agreement is terminated or the property is sold, the Owner **“shall honor all confirmed reservations.”** [4][7][13]

**Effect:**  
- Even after termination by **60 days written notice**, the Owner must:
  - Honor all **confirmed reservations**, and  
  - Pay or complete all obligations/expenses already incurred by the Agent. [4][7][13]

### 2.4. No Refund / Forfeiture Rule Stated

- The agreement does **not** specify any **refund** or **deposit forfeiture** mechanism tied to termination. [4][7][13]  
- There is no stated cancellation window for the Owner or Agent that triggers a refund of fees already paid. [4][7][13]

---

## 3. Holding Tank Servicing Contract (Contoso Ltd. ↔ Fabrikam Inc.)

**Document:** HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT [6][14]

### 3.1. Open‑Ended Term with Either‑Party Termination

- The contract states: **“This agreement will remain in effect until the owner or pumper terminates this contract.”** [6][14]  
- No specific notice period (e.g., days) is given for termination by either the owner or the pumper. [6][14]

**Effect:** Either party (Owner: Contoso Ltd.; Pumper: Fabrikam Inc.) may terminate at any time, but the contract does not specify a required notice period or form (written/oral). [6][14]

### 3.2. Post‑Termination Filing Requirement

- In the event of a **change in this contract**, the owner agrees to file:
  - A copy of any changes to this service contract, or  
  - A copy of a new service contract  
  with the municipality and the County within **ten (10) business days** from the date of change. [6][14]

**Connection to Termination:**  
- Termination is a “change in this contract,” so when the owner changes or replaces the service contract (including by termination and entering a new one), the owner must file the updated or new contract within **10 business days**. [6][14]

### 3.3. No Refund / Forfeiture Rule Stated

- The contract does **not** specify any **refund** or **deposit forfeiture** terms upon termination. [6][14]  
- Payment is described as “charges incurred in servicing the holding tank(s) as mutually agreed upon,” but no cancellation‑specific financial consequence is given. [6][14]

---

## 4. Purchase Contract for Lift (Contoso Lifts LLC ↔ Fabrikam Inc.)

**Document:** PURCHASE CONTRACT (lift purchase) [9][10][15]

### 4.1. Right to Cancel – 3 Business Days Cancellation Period

- The contract includes a **“Right to Cancel”** clause:  
  - “Customer may cancel within **3 business days** for full refund.” [9][10][15]  
- This is an explicit **3 business days cancellation period** from the effective date (mutual signature and initial payment). [9][10][15]

**Refund Outcome:**  
- If the customer cancels within **3 business days**, they receive a **full refund**. [9][10][15]

### 4.2. Deposit Forfeiture After Cancellation Period

- The same clause continues: **“Afterward, deposit is forfeited.”** [9][10][15]  
- “Deposit” refers to the initial payment, which is **$20,000.00 upon signing** as part of the total contract price of **$29,900.00**. [9][10][15]

**Effect:**  
- Cancellation **after** the **3 business days** window is still allowed, but the **deposit is forfeited**; the customer does not get the initial payment back. [9][10][15]

### 4.3. No Other Termination Mechanism Stated

- Apart from the **3 business days** right to cancel and the forfeiture rule after that period, the contract does **not** provide:
  - A general right for either party to terminate on notice (e.g., no “60 days written notice” clause). [9][10][15]  
- Other sections (Scope of Work, Payment Terms, Customer Default, Risk of Loss, Delivery, Applicable Law, Assignment, Warranty, Permitting) do not introduce additional termination or cancellation rights. [9][10][15]

---

## 5. Contoso Lifts LLC Invoice

**Document:** contoso_lifts_invoice [8]

- The invoice is a billing document and **does not contain any termination or cancellation mechanism**. [8]  
- It references “Initial payment in accordance with contract” and “Due on contract signing,” but all cancellation/termination rules are in the separate **Purchase Contract**, not in the invoice itself. [8][9][10][15]

---

## 6. Cross‑Document Connections and Entity Relationships

### 6.1. Contoso Ltd. Across Agreements

- **Contoso Ltd.** appears as:
  - Buyer/Owner in the **Builders Limited Warranty** with Fabrikam Inc. as Builder. [1][5][11]  
  - Property Owner in the **Property Management Agreement** with Walt Flood Realty. [4][7][13]  
  - Holding Tank Owner in the **Holding Tank Servicing Contract** with Fabrikam Inc. as Pumper. [6][14]

Across these:

- In the **warranty**, Contoso Ltd.’s rights terminate automatically after **1 year** or **60 days**, or upon sale/move‑out; arbitration survives termination. [1][2][3][5][11][12]  
- In the **property management agreement**, Contoso Ltd. can terminate with **60 days written notice**, but must honor all confirmed reservations and obligations incurred. [4][7][13]  
- In the **holding tank contract**, Contoso Ltd. can terminate at any time (no notice period specified), but must file any new or changed contract with the municipality and County within **10 business days**. [6][14]

### 6.2. Contoso Lifts LLC and the 3‑Day Cancellation

- **Contoso Lifts LLC** appears as:
  - Contractor in the **Purchase Contract** with Fabrikam Inc. (Customer). [9][10][15]  
  - Issuer of the **invoice** for a lift to Fabrikam Construction. [8]

The **3 business days cancellation period** and **deposit forfeiture** rules are defined in the **Purchase Contract**, not in the invoice. [9][10][15]  
The invoice simply references that payment is “Due on contract signing,” aligning with the **$20,000.00 upon signing** deposit that is subject to forfeiture if cancellation occurs after the **3 business days** window. [8][9][10][15]

### 6.3. Arbitration Survival vs. Agreement Termination

- The **Builders Limited Warranty** explicitly states that the **Arbitration Program** provisions **survive any termination, amendment, or expiration** of the warranty or related documents unless the parties agree otherwise in writing. [12]  
- This is a different pattern from the other agreements, which do not explicitly address survival of dispute resolution clauses after termination. [4][6][9][10][13][14][15]

---

## 7. Consolidated List of Notice Periods & Cancellation Windows

1. **Builders Limited Warranty (Fabrikam Inc. ↔ Contoso Ltd.)**  
   - Coverage termination: **1 year** or **60 days** after commencement, depending on the item. [1][2][3][5][11]  
   - Claim deadline: claims must be made in writing within **1 year** or **60 days**; otherwise not covered. [2][3][5][11]  
   - Automatic termination: upon sale of the home or move‑out by the first purchaser (no notice period specified). [1][2][3][5][11]  
   - Arbitration survival: arbitration provisions survive **termination, amendment, or expiration** unless otherwise agreed in writing. [12]

2. **Property Management Agreement (Contoso Ltd. ↔ Walt Flood Realty)**  
   - Initial term: **12 months** from **2010‑06‑15**. [4][7][13]  
   - Renewal: automatic **one year** renewals. [4][7][13]  
   - Termination right: either party may terminate with **60 days written notice**. [4][7][13]  
   - Post‑termination obligations: Owner must honor all **confirmed reservations** and all obligations/expenses incurred by Agent. [4][7][13]

3. **Holding Tank Servicing Contract (Contoso Ltd. ↔ Fabrikam Inc.)**  
   - Duration: remains in effect until owner or pumper terminates (no specific notice period). [6][14]  
   - Change/termination filing: owner must file any changed or new service contract within **10 business days** from the date of change. [6][14]

4. **Purchase Contract (Contoso Lifts LLC ↔ Fabrikam Inc.)**  
   - Right to cancel: Customer may cancel within **3 business days** for **full refund**. [9][10][15]  
   - After cancellation period: **deposit is forfeited** if cancellation occurs after the **3 business days** window. [9][10][15]  
   - Deposit amount: **$20,000.00 upon signing** as part of total **$29,900.00** contract price. [9][10][15]

5. **Contoso Lifts LLC Invoice**  
   - No termination or cancellation mechanism is stated in the invoice itself. [8]

---

This covers all termination and cancellation rules, notice periods, and refund/forfeiture outcomes across the provided agreements, with explicit numeric values and cross‑references to the relevant entities and documents.

runs.text:
1. The BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY document sets out Fabrikam Inc.’s one‑year and sixty‑day limited warranty obligations to Contoso Ltd. for a newly constructed home, details numerous exclusions and non‑warranted conditions, and requires most disputes to be resolved by binding arbitration under Idaho law rather than in court.[1][3][5][11][17]

2. The PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT appoints Walt Flood Realty as exclusive agent to manage Contoso Ltd.’s Honolulu rental property, defines the initial 12‑month term with automatic renewal for successive one‑year terms, and specifies each party’s responsibilities, fee structure, and Hawaii‑law governance.[4][7][13]

3. The HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT establishes an ongoing service arrangement between Contoso Ltd. as holding‑tank owner and Fabrikam Inc. as pumper, outlining filing obligations with Washburn County, access and maintenance duties, reporting requirements, and open‑ended duration until either party terminates.[6][12]

4. The contoso_lifts_invoice document is an itemized invoice from Contoso Lifts LLC to Fabrikam Construction for a vertical platform lift system and related components totaling $29,900.00, reflecting specific quantities, unit prices, and payment instructions.[8]

5. The PURCHASE CONTRACT defines the commercial agreement between Contoso Lifts LLC and Fabrikam Inc. for furnishing and installing a vertical platform lift system, including the detailed scope of work, a total contract price of $29,900.00 with three payment milestones, risk allocation, Florida governing law, warranty terms, and a three‑business‑day right to cancel.[9][10]

6. The EXHIBIT A – SCOPE OF WORK document supplements the lift purchase arrangement by specifying the exact equipment configuration (including that the ramp is “None” and pit depth is 3"), job location, site‑prep responsibilities, and execution by authorized representatives of Contoso Ltd. and Fabrikam Inc. on 04/30/2025.[14][15][16]

Q-G2.query: Identify which documents reference **jurisdictions / governing law**.

evidence_path_sig: Aluminum door with plexi-glass inserts & automatic opener
Power system: 110 VAC 60 Hz up, 12 VAC down
Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 2301 through 2312)
runs.text:
Documents that reference jurisdictions / governing law are:

---

## 1. BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY

### a. Arbitration and Idaho law

- The warranty contains an **Arbitration** section stating that, except for certain small claims, “all disputes are subject to binding arbitration.”[1][2][3][17]  
- A “Dispute” is defined to include any action, dispute, claim, or controversy that cannot be litigated in the **Small Claims Court of the State of Idaho**.[1][2][3][17]  
- The clause preserves the right to pursue claims “within the venue and jurisdiction of the Small Claims Department of the Magistrate Division of the District Courts of the State of Idaho as defined at Idaho Code § 1-2301, for claims for money which do not exceed $3,000.”[2][17]  
- Arbitration proceedings “shall otherwise resolve all Disputes in accordance with the applicable substantive law of the State of Idaho.”[2][3][17]  
- Arbitrations “shall be conducted in Pocatello, Idaho.”[2]  

These provisions collectively establish **Idaho** as the governing jurisdiction for disputes (substantive law and venue) under the Builders Limited Warranty between **Fabrikam Inc.** (Builder) and **Contoso Ltd.** (Buyer/Owner).[1][2][3][7][17]

### b. Federal law reference (Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act)

- The exclusions section states that the warranty “does not cover any appliance, piece of equipment, or other items which is a consumer product for purposes of the Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 2301 through 2312.).”[1][3][7][17]  

This is an explicit reference to a **U.S. federal statute** governing consumer product warranties, which is part of the applicable legal framework for certain items, even though the main governing law for disputes is Idaho law.[1][2][3][7][17]

---

## 2. PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT (Short Term and/or Vacation/Holiday Rentals)

### a. Governing law clause – State of Hawaii

- The agreement includes a section titled **“GOVERNING LAW.”**[4][6][9][13][14][15]  
- It states: “This is the entire Agreement between the parties and shall be governed by the laws of the State of Hawaii.”[4][6][9][13][14][15]  
- The same clause appears in the repeated “PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT” section on page 2.[6][9][13][14][15]  

Thus, this contract explicitly designates the **laws of the State of Hawaii** as the governing law for the property management relationship between **Contoso Ltd.** (Owner) and Walt Flood Realty (Agent).[4][6][9][13][14][15]

### b. Additional Hawaii jurisdiction references

- The Agent must deposit rents “in a special trust account in an insured financial institution authorized to do business in the State of Hawaii.”[4][9][13]  
- The Agent will assess/charge the Owner the “Hawaii Gross Excise tax (currently at 4.712%) on all the above fees, commissions and charges.”[4][6][9][13][14][15]  

These provisions reinforce that the property, financial institutions, and tax obligations are tied to **Hawaii** as the jurisdiction.[4][6][9][13][14][15]

---

## 3. PURCHASE CONTRACT (Contoso Lifts LLC – Fabrikam Inc.)

### a. Applicable law – State of Florida

- The contract has a section titled **“7. Applicable Law.”**[5][11][12]  
- It states: “This contract shall be governed by the laws of the State of Florida.”[5][11][12]  

This is an explicit governing law clause designating **Florida** as the jurisdiction whose laws apply to the purchase and installation contract between **Contoso Lifts LLC** (Contractor) and **Fabrikam Inc.** (Customer).[5][11][12]

### b. Florida-related context

- The Contractor’s address is “P.O. Box 123567 Key West, FL. 33304-0708.”[5][11][12]  
- The Customer’s address is “61 S 34th Street, Dayton, FL 33155.”[5][11][12]  

These Florida addresses align with the choice of **State of Florida** law as the governing law.[5][11][12]

---

## 4. HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT

- This contract references **Wisconsin** regulatory law but does **not** contain a general “governing law” or “applicable law” clause.  
- It states that the owner agrees to file a copy of the contract with the County of Washburn “as required under WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5.”[8][16]  

This is a reference to **Wisconsin administrative code** as a regulatory requirement, but not an explicit governing-law clause for the entire contract.[8][16]

---

## 5. CONTOSO LIFTS INVOICE

- The invoice from **Contoso Lifts LLC** lists Florida addresses and commercial terms but contains **no explicit governing law or jurisdiction clause.**[10]  

---

## Cross-document connections via entities

- **Contoso Ltd.** appears as Buyer/Owner in the **Builders Limited Warranty** governed substantively by Idaho law and referencing Idaho courts and arbitration in Pocatello, Idaho.[1][2][3][7][17]  
- The same **Contoso Ltd.** is Owner in the **Property Management Agreement**, which is governed by the laws of the State of Hawaii.[4][6][9][13][14][15]  
- **Fabrikam Inc.** appears as Builder in the Idaho-governed warranty[1][2][3][7][17], as Agent’s counterparty (Owner’s side) in the Hawaii-governed property management agreement (signing as principal broker for the Agent)[4][6][9][13][14][15], and as Customer in the Florida-governed purchase contract with **Contoso Lifts LLC**.[5][11][12]  
- **Contoso Lifts LLC** is party to the Florida-governed purchase contract[5][11][12] and also appears as the issuer on the invoice, which references the same Florida address but no governing law clause.[10]  
- The **Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 2301 through 2312)** is referenced in the Builders Limited Warranty as a federal law defining “consumer product” for purposes of warranty coverage exclusions.[1][3][7][17]  

---

## Direct answer to the query

**Documents that explicitly reference jurisdictions / governing law:**

1. **BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY**  
   - References the **State of Idaho** as the jurisdiction for small claims, arbitration venue (Pocatello, Idaho), and applicable substantive law for disputes.[1][2][3][17]  
   - References the **Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 2301 through 2312)** as applicable federal law for consumer products.[1][3][7][17]  

2. **PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT (Short Term and/or Vacation/Holiday Rentals)**  
   - Contains a “GOVERNING LAW” clause stating the agreement “shall be governed by the laws of the State of Hawaii.”[4][6][9][13][14][15]  
   - Also references the State of Hawaii for financial institutions and Hawaii Gross Excise tax at “4.712%.”[4][6][9][13][14][15]  

3. **PURCHASE CONTRACT**  
   - Contains an “Applicable Law” section stating: “This contract shall be governed by the laws of the State of Florida.”[5][11][12]  

**Documents that reference law or jurisdiction indirectly but do not have a general governing-law clause:**

4. **HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT**  
   - References **WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5** (Wisconsin code) as a filing requirement with the County of Washburn.[8][16]  

**Document without governing-law reference:**

5. **contoso_lifts_invoice**  
   - Contains no governing law or jurisdiction clause.[10]

runs.text:
Documents that reference jurisdictions / governing law are:

---

## 1. BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY

### a. Arbitration and Applicable Law (Governing Law by Implication)

- The warranty’s arbitration clause defines “Dispute” to include matters that cannot be litigated in the Small Claims Court of the **State of Idaho**, explicitly tying disputes to that jurisdiction’s small-claims court limits.[1][2][3][17]  
- The clause preserves the right to pursue claims “within the venue and jurisdiction of the Small Claims Department of the Magistrate Division of the District Courts of the **State of Idaho** as defined at Idaho Code § 1-2301, for claims for money which do not exceed $3,000.”[2][17]  
- Arbitration proceedings “shall otherwise resolve all Disputes in accordance with the applicable substantive law of the **State of Idaho**,” which is a governing-law specification for disputes under the warranty.[2][3][17]  
- Arbitrations “shall be conducted in Pocatello, Idaho,” specifying the place of arbitration within that jurisdiction.[2][17]  

**Connections via entities:**

- **Fabrikam Inc.** is the Builder issuing the limited warranty and is located at “1820 Summit Ridge Dr., Pocatello, ID 83201,” linking the Builder to Idaho as the governing jurisdiction for disputes.[1][7][17]  
- **Contoso Ltd.** is the Buyer/Owner of the property at “480 Willow Glen Drive, Chubbuck, ID 83202,” also in Idaho, reinforcing that the warranty and its dispute resolution are centered in Idaho.[1][7][17]  
- The defined term **“Dispute”** is expressly tied to arbitration governed by Idaho substantive law and Idaho small-claims jurisdiction.[1][2][3][17]  

**Numeric details related to jurisdiction/disputes:**

- Small claims carve‑out: claims “for money which do not exceed $3,000” may be brought in Idaho small claims court.[2][17]  
- Arbitration demand timing: not more than “60 days after service of a complaint, third party complaint, cross-claim or counterclaim or any answer thereto or any amendment to any of the above.”[1][3][17]  
- Arbitration conclusion target: parties agree “to conclude an arbitration… within 180 days of the filing of a Dispute.”[2]  

Although there is no standalone “Governing Law” heading, the requirement that arbitrators apply “the applicable substantive law of the State of Idaho” functions as a governing-law clause for disputes under this warranty.[2][3][17]  

---

## 2. PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT (Short Term and/or Vacation/Holiday Rentals)

### a. Explicit Governing Law Clause

- The agreement contains a section titled **“GOVERNING LAW”** stating: “This is the entire Agreement between the parties and shall be governed by the laws of the **State of Hawaii**.”[4][6][13][14][15]  
- The same clause states that the Agreement “shall be binding upon the successors and assigns of Owner or Agent,” but the key jurisdictional element is that Hawaii law governs.[4][6][13][14][15]  

### b. Jurisdictional Context

- The Agent, Walt Flood Realty, is described as “a Hawaii sole proprietorship,” and rents/manages property located at “456 Palm Tree Avenue, Honolulu, HI 96815,” further situating the contract in Hawaii.[4][9][13]  
- The agreement requires that rents be deposited in a financial institution “authorized to do business in the **State of Hawaii**,” reinforcing the Hawaii legal and regulatory context.[4][9][13]  
- The Agent will assess the “Hawaii Gross Excise tax (currently at 4.712%)” on fees, which is a Hawaii-specific tax regime tied to that jurisdiction.[6][9][13][14][15]  

**Connections via entities:**

- **Governing Law** entity is explicitly linked to this agreement through the “GOVERNING LAW” heading and the statement that Hawaii law governs.[4][6]  
- **State of Hawaii** is the jurisdiction named in the governing-law clause and in operational provisions (banking authorization, tax).[4][6][13][14][15]  
- **Contoso Ltd.** is the Owner under this agreement, so its rights and obligations regarding the property at 456 Palm Tree Avenue are governed by Hawaii law.[4][9][13]  
- **Fabrikam Inc.** appears as the signatory for the Agent (principal broker), tying Fabrikam’s role in this document to Hawaii law, distinct from its Idaho-based warranty in the Builders Limited Warranty.[4][6][9][13][14][15]  

**Numeric details related to jurisdiction:**

- Hawaii Gross Excise tax rate is stated as “4.712%” on the Agent’s fees, commissions, and charges.[6][9][13][14][15]  

---

## 3. PURCHASE CONTRACT (Vertical Platform Lift – Contoso Lifts LLC / Fabrikam Inc.)

### a. Applicable Law (Governing Law Clause)

- Section **“7. Applicable Law”** states: “This contract shall be governed by the laws of the **State of Florida**.”[5][11][12]  
- This is an explicit governing-law clause specifying Florida as the jurisdiction whose laws apply to the contract between **Contoso Lifts LLC** (Contractor) and **Fabrikam Inc.** (Customer).[5][11][12]  

### b. Jurisdictional Context

- Contoso Lifts LLC is located at “P.O. Box 123567 Key West, FL. 33304-0708,” and Fabrikam Inc. is located at “61 S 34th Street, Dayton, FL 33155,” both Florida addresses, aligning the governing-law choice with the parties’ locations.[5][11][12]  

**Connections via entities:**

- **Contoso Lifts LLC** is the Contractor; its Florida address and the Florida governing-law clause connect this entity to Florida jurisdiction.[5][11][12]  
- **Fabrikam Inc.** is the Customer here, so its rights and obligations under this purchase contract are governed by Florida law, in contrast to its Idaho-governed Builders Limited Warranty and Hawaii-governed Property Management Agreement.[1][4][5][7][9][11][12][13]  
- The **Applicable Law** entity is directly represented by Section 7, which names the State of Florida as the governing law.[5]  

**Numeric details related to jurisdictional clause context:**

- While the governing-law clause itself is qualitative, the contract includes Florida-based performance and payment obligations, such as a total contract price of “$29,900.00” payable in three installments of “$20,000.00,” “$7,000.00,” and “$2,900.00,” all of which are subject to Florida law by virtue of the Applicable Law clause.[5][11][12]  

---

## 4. HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT

### a. Jurisdictional Indicators (Regulatory Reference, but No Explicit Governing-Law Clause)

- The contract requires the owner to file a copy of the contract “with the County of Washburn, as required under WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5,” which is a reference to **Wisconsin** administrative code and thus to Wisconsin jurisdiction.[8][16]  
- The property address is “123 Mockup Lane, Washburn County, WI,” further situating the contract’s performance in Wisconsin.[8][16]  

However, the document does **not** contain an explicit “Governing Law” or “Applicable Law” clause; instead, it references Wisconsin law and county filing requirements, which are jurisdictional but not framed as a governing-law provision.[8][16]  

**Connections via entities:**

- **Contoso Ltd.** is the Holding Tank Owner, and **Fabrikam Inc.** is the Pumper, both operating under obligations tied to Wisconsin code and Washburn County requirements.[8][16]  

---

## 5. CONTOSO LIFTS INVOICE

- The invoice lists Contoso Lifts LLC at “P.O. Box 123567 Key West, FL. 33304-0708” and Fabrikam Construction at “61 S 34th Street, Dayton, FL 33155,” both Florida addresses, but it does **not** contain any clause specifying governing law or jurisdiction.[10]  
- It references that the payment is “in accordance with contract,” implying that jurisdiction and governing law are determined by the underlying **Purchase Contract**, which is governed by Florida law.[5][10][11][12]  

**Connections via entities:**

- **Contoso Lifts LLC** appears here as the invoicing party, consistent with its role as Contractor in the Florida-governed Purchase Contract.[5][10][11][12]  

---

## 6. Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act Reference

- The Builders Limited Warranty states that it “does not cover any appliance, piece of equipment, or other items which is a consumer product for purposes of the **Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 2301 through 2312.)**”[1][3][7][17]  
- This is a reference to U.S. federal law governing consumer product warranties, but it is used as a coverage exclusion rather than as a governing-law clause for the contract as a whole.[1][3][7][17]  

**Connections via entities:**

- The **Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 2301 through 2312)** entity is linked to the Builders Limited Warranty’s exclusions, showing interaction between Idaho-governed warranty disputes and federal warranty law for certain consumer products.[1][3][7][17]  

---

## Consolidated Answer to the Query

1. **Documents with explicit governing-law / applicable-law clauses:**
   - **PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT** – Contains a “GOVERNING LAW” section stating the agreement “shall be governed by the laws of the State of Hawaii.”[4][6][13][14][15]

2. **Documents that reference jurisdiction / governing law by specifying applicable state law for disputes or regulatory compliance (even if not under a “Governing Law” heading):**
   - **BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY** – Arbitration clause requires disputes to be resolved in accordance with “the applicable substantive law of the State of Idaho,” and preserves access to Idaho small claims courts for claims up to $3,000.[1][2][3][17]

4. **Federal law reference:**

Documents that reference jurisdictions / governing law are:

---

## 1. BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY

### a. Arbitration governed by Idaho law and courts

- The warranty’s arbitration clause defines “Dispute” to include matters that cannot be litigated in the Small Claims Court of the **State of Idaho**.[1][2][3][17]  
- It preserves the right of any party to pursue claims “within the venue and jurisdiction of the Small Claims Department of the Magistrate Division of the District Courts of the State of Idaho as defined at Idaho Code § 1-2301, for claims for money which do not exceed $3,000.”[2][17]  
- Arbitration is to be administered by the American Arbitration Association (“AAA”) or another agreed administrator, and “the arbitrator(s) shall otherwise resolve all Disputes in accordance with the applicable substantive law of the State of Idaho.”[2][3][17]  
- “Arbitrations shall be conducted in Pocatello, Idaho,” specifying the geographic forum.[2]  

These provisions collectively establish Idaho as the governing jurisdiction for dispute resolution under the Builders Limited Warranty between **Fabrikam Inc.** (Builder) and **Contoso Ltd.** (Buyer/Owner).[1][7][17]

---

## 2. PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT (Short Term and/or Vacation/Holiday Rentals)

### a. Governing law clause – State of Hawaii

- The agreement is titled “PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT (Short Term and/or Vacation/Holiday Rentals)” and is between **Contoso Ltd.** as “Owner” and Walt Flood Realty as “Agent.”[4][9][13]  
- The “GOVERNING LAW” section states: “This is the entire Agreement between the parties and shall be governed by the laws of the **State of Hawaii**. This Agreement shall be binding upon the successors and assigns of Owner or Agent.”[4][6][13][14][15]  
- The Agent must deposit rents “in a special trust account in an insured financial institution authorized to do business in the State of Hawaii,” further tying performance to Hawaii jurisdiction.[4][9][13]  

Thus, this document explicitly designates the **State of Hawaii** as the governing law for the property management relationship involving the Hawaii property at “456 Palm Tree Avenue, Honolulu, HI 96815.”[4][9][13]

---

## 3. PURCHASE CONTRACT (Contoso Lifts LLC – Fabrikam Inc.)

### a. Applicable law – State of Florida

- The “PURCHASE CONTRACT” is between **Contoso Lifts LLC** (Contractor) and **Fabrikam Inc.** (Customer).[5][11][12]  
- Section “7. Applicable Law” states: “This contract shall be governed by the laws of the **State of Florida**.”[5][11][12]  
- The parties’ addresses are in Florida: Contoso Lifts LLC at “P.O. Box 123567 Key West, FL. 33304-0708” and Fabrikam Inc. at “61 S 34th Street, Dayton, FL 33155,” reinforcing the Florida nexus.[5][11][12]  

This clause makes Florida the governing jurisdiction for the elevator/lift purchase and installation contract, including related disputes such as “Customer Default” and “Risk of Loss.”[5][11][12]

---

## 4. HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT

### a. Regulatory jurisdiction – Wisconsin (implicit governing framework)

- The contract is for a holding tank at “123 Mockup Lane, Washburn County, WI.”[8][16]  
- It requires the owner to file a copy of the contract “with the County of Washburn, as required under **WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5**.”[8][16]  
- The pumper must submit reports “to the County” and include specified information such as permit numbers and disposal sites.[8][16]  

While there is no explicit “governing law” clause, the reference to **WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5** and filing with Washburn County indicates that Wisconsin law and county regulation govern the servicing obligations.[8][16]

---

## 5. CONTOSO LIFTS INVOICE

- The invoice from **Contoso Lifts LLC** to Fabrikam Construction lists Florida addresses (“P.O. Box 123567 Key West, FL. 33304-0708” and “61 S 34th Street, Dayton, FL 33155”) but does **not** contain any explicit governing law or jurisdiction clause.[10]  
- It references that the payment is “in accordance with contract,” implying that jurisdiction/governing law would be determined by the related **Purchase Contract**, which is governed by the laws of the State of Florida.[5][10][11][12]  

---

## 6. Cross‑document connections via governing law / jurisdiction

- **Fabrikam Inc.** appears in multiple documents under different governing regimes:
  - As Builder in the Builders Limited Warranty, where disputes are arbitrated under Idaho substantive law and Idaho small claims jurisdiction is preserved.[1][2][3][7][17]  
  - As Owner in the Hawaii Property Management Agreement, which is governed by the laws of the State of Hawaii.[4][6][9][13][14][15]  
  - As Customer in the Florida Purchase Contract with Contoso Lifts LLC, governed by the laws of the State of Florida.[5][11][12]  
  - As Pumper in the Holding Tank Servicing Contract, subject to Wisconsin’s WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5 and Washburn County requirements.[8][16]  

- **Contoso Ltd.** is:
  - Buyer/Owner under the Idaho‑based Builders Limited Warranty.[1][3][7][17]  
  - Owner under the Hawaii‑governed Property Management Agreement.[4][9][13][14][15]  
  - Holding Tank Owner under the Wisconsin‑regulated Holding Tank Servicing Contract.[8][16]  

- **Contoso Lifts LLC**:
  - Issues the Purchase Contract governed by Florida law.[5][11][12]  
  - Issues an invoice that references the same Florida address and ties payment to that contract, thereby indirectly linking the invoice to Florida jurisdiction.[5][10][11][12]  

- The **Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 2301 through 2312)** is referenced in the Builders Limited Warranty as a federal law defining “consumer product” for purposes of warranty exclusions, but it is not itself a governing-law clause; instead, it is used to exclude coverage for items that are consumer products under that Act.[1][3][7][17]  

---

### Direct answer to the query

Documents that reference jurisdictions or governing law (explicitly or via regulatory jurisdiction) are:

1. **BUILDERS LIMITED WARRANTY** – references the State of Idaho (small claims court, Idaho Code § 1-2301, substantive law of the State of Idaho, arbitrations in Pocatello, Idaho).[1][2][3][17]  
2. **PROPERTY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT** – contains a “GOVERNING LAW” clause stating the agreement “shall be governed by the laws of the State of Hawaii.”[4][6][9][13][14][15]  
3. **PURCHASE CONTRACT** – contains an “Applicable Law” clause stating the contract “shall be governed by the laws of the State of Florida.”[5][11][12]  
4. **HOLDING TANK SERVICING CONTRACT** – ties obligations to Wisconsin jurisdiction by requiring filing with Washburn County and compliance with WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5.[8][16]  

The **contoso_lifts_invoice** does not itself state governing law but is connected to the Florida‑governed Purchase Contract through shared parties, addresses, and the note “Initial payment in accordance with contract.”[5][10][11][12]

runs.text:
Below is a “who pays what” summary across the relevant agreements and invoice, organized by document and then cross‑referenced.

---

## 1. Property Management Agreement (Hawaii rental property)

**Parties:**  
- Owner: Contoso Ltd. (“Owner”)  
- Agent: Walt Flood Realty (“Agent”) [1][4]

### 1.1. Agent’s fees – paid by Owner

Under “AGENT’S FEES. Owner is advised and agrees to pay the following,” the Owner must pay all listed fees and charges to the Agent. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

Owner pays:

1. **Credit card/bankcard fees**  
   - Agent is allowed to accept credit cards and deduct credit card and/or bankcard fees from the Owner’s proceeds. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

2. **Management commission on rentals**  
   - **25% of gross revenues** for management services for short term and/or vacation rentals (reservations of less than 180 days). [1][2][3][4][5][6]  
   - **10% of gross revenues** for management services for long term leases (leases of more than 180 days). [1][2][3][4][5][6]

3. **Advertising charge (short‑term rentals)**  
   - Pro‑ration charge for advertising at **$75.00/month**. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

4. **Administration and accounting charge**  
   - Minimum charge of **$50.00/month** (not including tax preparation/returns/forms). [1][2][3][4][5][6]

5. **Fee on repairs/upgrades/renovations**  
   - **10% fee** on the total charge for repairs, upgrades, and/or renovations. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

6. **Hourly charge for scheduling/escorting work**  
   - **$35/hour** to schedule repairs, upgrades, renovations, replacement of appliances, carpets, curtains, drapes, and/or to escort contractors, repair persons, technicians and handymen. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

7. **Hawaii Gross Excise Tax on all of the above**  
   - Agent will assess/charge the Owner the **Hawaii Gross Excise tax (currently at 4.712%)** on all the above fees, commissions and charges. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

8. **Agency start‑up fee**  
   - Upon execution, Owner must pay **$250.00** to the Agent as a **non‑refundable start‑up fee**. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

### 1.2. Other Owner obligations with financial implications

Owner also agrees to:  

- Provide Agent with Owner’s **General Excise Tax License** (indicating Owner is responsible for its own Hawaii GET compliance on rental income). [4]  
- Provide Agent with Owner’s **U.S. Federal Tax Id or Social Security number** (for tax reporting). [4]  
- Provide **Liability Insurance** with minimum limits of **$300,000** for bodily injury and **$25,000** for property damage to others, naming Agent as additional insured. [4]

These are costs borne by the Owner (license, tax compliance, insurance premiums), though the exact dollar amounts beyond the minimum coverage limits are not specified. [4]

---

## 2. Builder’s Limited Warranty with Arbitration (home construction/purchase)

**Parties:**  
- Builder: Fabrikam Inc. (“Builder”) [7][9]  
- Buyer/Owner: Contoso Ltd. (“Buyer/Owner”) [7][9]

### 2.1. Who pays arbitration costs and sanctions

Under the arbitration program:

1. **Allocation of arbitration costs and fees**  
   - “Each party shall be responsible to pay for one‑half (1/2) of the cost and fees of the arbitration and their respective costs including attorneys’ fees in any arbitration.” [15][16][17]  
   → Both Builder (Fabrikam Inc.) and Buyer/Owner (Contoso Ltd.) each pay **½ of the arbitration costs and fees**, and each pays its own attorneys’ fees. [7][9][15][16][17]

2. **Arbitrator sanctions**  
   - “The arbitrator(s) shall be empowered to impose sanctions for any Party’s failure to proceed within the times established herein.” [15][16][17]  
   → Any party that fails to proceed timely can be sanctioned by the arbitrator; the sanctioned party bears those sanctions (though the exact monetary amount is not specified). [15][16][17]

3. **Costs when a party refuses arbitration after a lawful demand**  
   - Any party who fails to submit to binding arbitration following a lawful demand “shall bear all costs and expenses, including reasonable attorneys’ fees … incurred by the other Party in obtaining a stay of any pending judicial proceeding and compelling arbitration of any Dispute.” [7][9]  
   → The non‑complying party pays **all costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees** incurred by the other party to force arbitration. [7][9]

### 2.2. Self‑help remedies – who bears what

The arbitration clause preserves certain remedies:

- Parties may **exercise self‑help remedies (including repossession and set‑off rights)**. [15][16][17]  
- They may also pursue **liens, foreclosure, provisional or ancillary remedies** such as injunctive relief, sequestration, attachment, claim & delivery, replevin, garnishment, or appointment of a receiver. [15][16][17]

The contract does not assign specific fees or taxes to these self‑help remedies, but any **claim or Dispute related to exercise of any self‑help, auxiliary or other rights** is itself a “Dispute” subject to the arbitration program (and thus the ½‑and‑½ cost split and potential sanctions described above). [15][16][17]

---

## 3. Holding Tank Servicing Contract (septic/holding tank service)

**Parties:**  
- Holding Tank Owner: Contoso Ltd. [8][10]  
- Pumper: Fabrikam Inc. [8][10]

### 3.1. Who pays service charges

1. **Service charges for pumping/servicing**  
   - The owner agrees “to have the holding tank(s) serviced by the pumper” and “further agrees to pay the pumper for all charges incurred in servicing the holding tank(s) as mutually agreed upon by the owner and pumper.” [8][10]  
   → Contoso Ltd. (Owner) pays **all charges for servicing** the holding tank(s), at rates mutually agreed with Fabrikam Inc. (Pumper). [8][10]

2. **Access road/drive maintenance**  
   - The owner agrees “to maintain the all‑weather access road or drive so that the pumper can service the holding tank(s) with the pumping equipment.” [8][10]  
   → Owner bears the cost of maintaining the access road/drive. [8][10]

3. **Regulatory filing obligations**  
   - Owner agrees to file a copy of the contract with the County of Washburn as required under WI Code SPS 383.21(2)5. [8][10]  
   - In case of changes or a new service contract, the owner agrees to file a copy with the municipality and County within **ten (10) business days** from the date of change. [8][10]  
   → Any filing fees or compliance costs associated with these filings fall on the Owner (Contoso Ltd.), though specific dollar amounts are not stated. [8][10]

4. **Pumper’s reporting obligations (no explicit charge to owner)**  
   - The pumper agrees to submit reports to the County including: responsible person, owner name, property location, sanitary permit number, service dates, volumes pumped, disposal sites, and condition of tank/components. [8][10]  
   → The contract does not state that the Owner pays separately for these reporting obligations; they appear to be part of the pumper’s duties under the service arrangement. [8][10]

---

## 4. Purchase Contract – Vertical Platform Lift (Florida)

**Parties:**  
- Contractor: Contoso Lifts LLC (Contractor) [12][13]  
- Customer: Fabrikam Inc. (Customer) [12][13]

### 4.1. Contract price and payment schedule – paid by Customer

1. **Total contract price**  
   - “Total contract price is $29,900.00, payable in 3 installments.” [12][13]

2. **Installment schedule** – all paid by Customer (Fabrikam Inc.) to Contractor (Contoso Lifts LLC):  
   - **$20,000.00 upon signing**. [12][13]  
   - **$7,000.00 upon delivery**. [12][13]  
   - **$2,900.00 upon completion**. [12][13]

3. **Changes**  
   - Any changes must be agreed in writing and “will affect the next payment milestone.” [12][13]  
   → Customer’s payment obligations may increase or shift timing if changes are made, but the exact amounts depend on the agreed change. [12][13]

### 4.2. Legal fees and default

1. **Customer default**  
   - “Failure to pay may result in legal action. Legal fees are recoverable by Contractor.” [12][13]  
   → If Fabrikam Inc. (Customer) defaults and Contractor sues, **Customer ultimately pays Contractor’s legal fees** (to the extent recoverable). [12][13]

### 4.3. Risk of loss and compliance costs

1. **Risk of loss**  
   - Contractor holds risk until delivery; Customer holds risk thereafter. [12][13]  
   → While not a fee, this allocates who bears financial loss from damage: Contractor before delivery, Customer after. [12][13]

2. **Permitting and compliance costs**  
   - “Contractor assists with permitting. Customer bears any additional compliance costs.” [12][13]  
   → Fabrikam Inc. (Customer) pays any extra costs required to comply with permitting or other regulatory requirements beyond the Contractor’s assistance. [12][13]

3. **Right to cancel and deposit**  
   - Customer may cancel within **3 business days** for a **full refund**. [12][13]  
   - Afterward, **deposit is forfeited**. [12][13]  
   → If Customer cancels after 3 business days, Customer loses the deposit already paid (part of the $29,900.00), effectively paying that amount without receiving the lift. [12][13]

---

## 5. Contoso Lifts Invoice #1256003 (equipment invoice)

**Issuer:** Contoso Lifts LLC (same entity as Contractor in the purchase contract) [11][14]  
**Customer:** John Doe / Fabrikam Construction [11][14]

### 5.1. Line items and who pays

The invoice lists quantities, descriptions, and prices, with a **SUBTOTAL of 29900.00**, **TAX N/A**, and **TOTAL 29900.00**, with **AMOUNT DUE 29900.00**. [11][14]

Line items (all payable by the invoice recipient, John Doe / Fabrikam Construction):

- 1 Vertical Platform Lift (Savaria V1504) – **11200.00**. [11][14]  
- 1 110 VAC 60 Hz up, 12 VAC down operation parts – **3000.00**. [11][14]  
- 1 Special Size 42" x 62" cab with 90 degree Type 3 – **5800.00**. [11][14]  
- 1 Outdoor fitting – **2000.00**. [11][14]  
- 1 80" High low profile aluminum door with plexi‑glass inserts, WR‑500 lock, automatic door operator – **5000.00**. [11][14]  
- 2 Hall Call stations for bottom and upper landing at **1450.00** each, total **2900.00**. [11][14]

Totals:

- **SUBTOTAL 29900.00**. [11][14]  
- **TAX N/A** (no tax charged on this invoice). [11][14]  
- **TOTAL 29900.00**. [11][14]  
- **AMOUNT DUE 29900.00**. [11][14]

The invoice states “Initial payment in accordance with contract” and “Due on contract signing,” indicating this amount is due from the customer at contract signing. [11][14]

---

## 6. Cross‑document connections and “who pays what” across entities

### 6.1. Hawaii Gross Excise Tax vs. other taxes

- In the **Property Management Agreement**, the Agent explicitly charges the Owner **Hawaii Gross Excise tax (currently at 4.712%)** on all Agent’s fees, commissions, and charges. [1][2][3][4][5][6]  
- In the **Contoso Lifts invoice**, tax is listed as **“TAX N/A”**, so no sales or excise tax is charged on that invoice. [11][14]  
- The **Purchase Contract** for the lift does not separately mention sales tax or excise tax; it only states the total contract price of **$29,900.00** and the installment schedule. [12][13]  
  → Thus, only the Hawaii property management context explicitly passes a tax (Hawaii Gross Excise tax at 4.712%) through to the paying party (Owner). [1][2][3][4][5][6]

### 6.2. Self‑help remedies and arbitrator sanctions (Builder’s warranty)

- The **Builder’s Limited Warranty** preserves **self‑help remedies (including repossession and set‑off rights)** for any party, without specifying separate fees for exercising them. [15][16][17]  
- Any dispute about these self‑help actions is arbitrated, with each party paying **½ of arbitration costs** and its own attorneys’ fees, and with arbitrators empowered to impose sanctions for delay. [15][16][17]  
- If a party refuses arbitration after a lawful demand, that party must pay **all costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees** incurred by the other party to compel arbitration. [7][9]

### 6.3. Agent’s fees vs. Contractor’s fees vs. Service charges

- **Agent’s fees (Hawaii property management):**  
  - Paid by Owner (Contoso Ltd.) to Agent (Walt Flood Realty), including percentage commissions, monthly charges, hourly charges, and Hawaii Gross Excise tax at 4.712%. [1][2][3][4][5][6]

- **Contractor’s price and legal fees (lift purchase):**  
  - Paid by Customer (Fabrikam Inc.) to Contractor (Contoso Lifts LLC): total **$29,900.00** in three installments. [12][13]  
  - If Customer defaults, Contractor can recover legal fees from Customer. [12][13]

- **Holding tank service charges:**  
  - Paid by Owner (Contoso Ltd.) to Pumper (Fabrikam Inc.) for all charges incurred in servicing the holding tank(s), plus Owner maintains access road and handles filings. [8][10]

- **Invoice #1256003 charges:**  
  - Paid by John Doe / Fabrikam Construction to Contoso Lifts LLC: **$29,900.00** total, with no tax charged (TAX N/A). [11][14]

---

### 6.4. Summary table of “who pays what”

- **Contoso Ltd. (as Owner in Hawaii property management)**  
  - Pays Agent’s commissions: **25%** (short‑term) or **10%** (long‑term) of gross revenues. [1][2][3][4][5][6]  
  - Pays advertising **$75.00/month**, admin/accounting **$50.00/month**, 10% fee on repairs/upgrades/renovations, $35/hour scheduling/escort, and **$250.00** non‑refundable start‑up fee. [1][2][3][4][5][6]  
  - Pays **Hawaii Gross Excise tax 4.712%** on all these fees/charges. [1][2][3][4][5][6]  
  - Pays for liability insurance and bears its own tax compliance costs. [4]

- **Contoso Ltd. (as Holding Tank Owner)**  
  - Pays all charges for servicing the holding tank(s) to Fabrikam Inc. (Pumper). [8][10]  
  - Pays to maintain all‑weather access road/drive and to file required contracts/changes with County/municipality. [8][10]

- **Contoso Ltd. (as Buyer/Owner in Builder’s warranty)**  
  - Pays **½ of arbitration costs and fees** and its own attorneys’ fees in any arbitration. [15][16][17]  
  - If Contoso Ltd. refuses arbitration after a lawful demand, it must pay all costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees incurred by Fabrikam Inc. to compel arbitration. [7][9]

- **Fabrikam Inc. (as Builder in warranty)**  
  - Pays **½ of arbitration costs and fees** and its own attorneys’ fees in any arbitration. [15][16][17]  
  - If Fabrikam Inc. refuses arbitration after a lawful demand, it must pay all costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees incurred by Contoso Ltd. to compel arbitration. [7][9]

- **Fabrikam Inc. (as Pumper in holding tank contract)**  
  - Receives payment from Contoso Ltd. for all servicing charges. [8][10]  
  - Bears its own cost of preparing and submitting required reports to the County (no separate charge to Owner specified). [8][10]

- **Fabrikam Inc. (as Customer in lift purchase contract)**  
  - Pays Contactor (Contoso Lifts LLC) **$29,900.00** in three installments: **$20,000.00 upon signing**, **$7,000.00 upon delivery**, **$2,900.00 upon completion**. [12][13]  
  - Bears any additional compliance costs related to permitting. [12][13]  
  - If it defaults, it may be liable for Contractor’s legal fees. [12][13]

- **John Doe / Fabrikam Construction (as invoice customer)**  
  - Pays Contoso Lifts LLC **AMOUNT DUE 29900.00**, with **TAX N/A**. [11][14]

This captures the allocation of fees, charges, taxes, and key cost responsibilities across the agreements and invoice, with explicit numeric values and the roles of each party.
